I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  A South Asia Regional Department climate change implementation plan consultative 
mission was fielded in March 2009. During this time, the Government of Sri Lanka requested the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) to assist the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources 
(MENR) to support climate change adaptation strengthening efforts. This request is in line with 
an important focus of the Sri Lanka country partnership strategy (CPS) 2009–2011,1 approved 
in  October  2008,  which  aims  to  (i)  strengthen  capacity  at  line  agencies  to  implement 
environmental  and  social  safeguards,  and  (ii)  promote  climate  change  initiatives.  ADB 
responded to this request by fielding a fact-finding mission in May 2009 to formulate capacity 
development technical assistance (TA). Bilateral discussions were held with senior officials of 
MENR, the Centre for Poverty Analysis, Television for Education Asia Pacific and other climate 
change  experts  both  from  within  the  Government  and  other  institutions.  Preliminary 
understandings and agreements were reached on the TA impact, outcome, implementation 
arrangements,  cost  estimates,  and  consultants’  terms  of  reference.2  The  TA  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.   As a result of its densely populated and relatively low-lying coastline, Sri Lanka remains 
highly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. Sea level rise poses a threat to coastal 
assets,  livelihoods,  and  fragile  coastal  and  marine  habitats.  At  the  same  time,  raised 
temperatures and unpredictable monsoon patterns are already showing signs of affecting the 
country’s  agricultural  productivity.  These  key  risks  were  among  those  identified  by  the 
Government in its initial national communications on climate change, developed as part of its 
commitments to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and 
highlighted in the Government’s Green Lanka program as priority areas requiring action. The 
Government  has  embarked  on  preparation  of  its  second  National  Communication  Study 
(2nd NATCOM), which it aims to complete by the middle of 2010. This is a large undertaking 
that requires scientific assessments of predicted climate trends and their sectoral impacts. The 
overall responsibility of the 2nd NATCOM rests with the recently formed National Advisory 
Council on Climate Change within MENR, with representation from relevant line ministries and 
agencies. The NATCOM process is partially supported by Global Environmental Facility Funds. 
 
3.  As a direct result of the NATCOM process, there is emerging momentum in Sri Lanka on 
climate-related  activities,  and  substantial  effort  in  government  departments  and  research 
institutions3 to understand and manage the impacts of climate change in a meaningful way—
particularly on agriculture and water resources, which are key sectors for Sri Lanka’s economic 
development.  Within  MENR,  a  Climate  Change  Secretariat  headed  by  a  director  has 
responsibility over several separate units, covering both adaptation and mitigation aspects. This 
secretariat, among other functions, is (i) the platform to address all climate change issues at the 
national level, (ii) the dedicated institutional mechanism on climate change responses, and 
(iii) the repository of all climate change related data. It also facilitates climate change research 
and distribution of research results to trigger policy reforms and actions, and provides a one-
step  facility  to  develop  and  disseminate  project  information  relating  to  implementation  of 
UNFCCC and Conference of the Parties meetings. Where the secretariat is involved in activities 
that concern other line ministries and agencies, steering committees are set up comprising

government department representatives and individual experts. Among civil society, there is 
increased awareness of the importance of addressing climate change adaptation responses, 
and  recognition  that  this  be  conducted  with  full  stakeholder  consultation  and  involvement. 
Practical  Action4  has  taken  a  lead  supporting  role  in  this  activity,  in  conjunction  with  the 
Government, and is currently engaged in a series of consultations in the Western, Eastern, and 
Southern provinces of the island.  
 
4.  Climate change is likely to threaten the significant achievements Sri Lanka has made in 
the last 20 years in increasing incomes and reducing poverty. Climate change and variability 
pose significant threats to the achievement of long-term development goals, especially those 
related to eliminating poverty and hunger, ensuring food and health security, human rights, and 
promoting  environmental  sustainability.  Climate  change  induced  vulnerability  and  natural 
disasters have amplified the problems of environmental degradation, and have led to serious 
deterioration  of  ecosystem  goods  and  services  –  adding  yet  another  dimension  to  the 
persistence of poverty. It is now acknowledged that attempts to reduce poverty will only be 
sustainable over the longer term if they simultaneously address climate change issues in the 
development process.  
 
5.  Sri Lanka recognizes that climate change impacts will affect vulnerable populations that 
will be impacted by changes, including coastal communities and rural farming communities 
reliant  on  water  resources.  According  to  the  outcomes  of  the  national  capacity  self 
assessment,5 significant challenges lie in responding institutionally to the impacts of climate 
variability  and  extreme  weather,  developing  risk  management  procedures  and  a  holistic 
adaptation  strategy,  and  strengthening  climate  change  risk  management  capacities  at  the 
national and local levels—where, for example, district environment and agriculture officers are 
often stretched in terms of the geographical areas they cover, and limited in their technical 
capacity to provide advice to stakeholders with legitimate concerns relating to changing weather 
patterns and their effects on crop selection, suitability, productivity, etc. The assessment also 
indicated that improved public awareness of climate change risks and adaptation techniques is 
a priority area for action, particularly in rural areas. 
 
6.  Opportunities for ADB support. At present, there is a large disparity in the level of 
education, information, and awareness on climate change risks, issues, and responses at the 
regional, national, and local levels, and within vulnerable sectors. There are also serious human 
resource requirements in terms of adequately trained officials at the central and local level to 
manage the growing manifestations and impacts of climate change. With this background, by 
attempting to address these gaps, the TA will support the CPS 2009–2011 to (i) strengthen 
capacity at line agencies to implement environmental safeguards that take into account climate 
change impacts through risk proofing, and training, etc., (ii) assist MENR mainstream climate 
change initiatives in the development planning process (as outlined in the Government’s Ten 
Year Development Framework); and (iii) promote climate change initiatives. Overall, the TA will 
provide  ADB  with  a  unique  opportunity  to  assume  a  major  development  partner  role  in 
facilitating and negotiating for adaptation programming in Sri Lanka. It will also enable MENR to 
play a strategic role over the longer term in building capacity within other ministries and line 
agencies  to  manage  climate  change  adaptation  planning  effectively  within  their  respective 
sectors.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact of the TA will be increased resilience within Sri Lanka to climate change 
impacts  in  support  of  sustainable  economic  development  and  conservation  of  the  natural 
environment.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be  improved  effectiveness  of  environmental 
management and better organization of concerned stakeholders to address climate change—
resulting  in  an  enabling  strategy  for  climate  change  adaptation,  with  increased  public 
awareness, and strengthened institutional capacities of the agencies concerned.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The  TA  will  have  the  following  outputs:  (i)  a  strategic  program  for  climate  change 
adaptation, including the development of a climate change adaptation strategy, (ii) a priority 
action plan and investment strategy for projects focused on climate change adaptation, (iii) an 
institutional  development  strategy  with  a  program  of  capacity  development  and  training 
requirements, and (iv) an information and awareness program. This will involve working with a 
variety  of  stakeholders,  including  relevant  ministries  and  line  agencies,  nongovernment 
organizations, academia, media and education representatives, and affected communities. In 
this  way  and  through  MENR’s  engagement  with  a  range  of  partners  the  strategy  that  is 
developed will be responsive to other stakeholders’ needs, and the reality on the ground. 
Development of the action plan and investment strategy will involve close coordination and 
interaction with the MOFP, as the prescribed work draws on its core area of competence.  
 
9.  The main outputs and activities of the TA are described below:  
 
(i)  Strategic  program  for  climate  change  adaptation.  ADB  interventions  will 
support Sri Lanka’s pioneering efforts in developing a country-driven strategic 
program  for  climate  change  adaptation—expediting  access  to  financing  for 
priority  adaptation  measures.  A  climate  change  adaptation  strategy  will  be 
formulated as part of this component. The TA will also support the involvement of 
key stakeholders at national and local levels in developing a strategic program 
and  medium-term  investment  plan  that  will  prioritize  and  identify  activities 
required  to  address  climate  change  adaptation  risks  and  sustainable 
environmental management at the national and local levels. This process will be 
coordinated  with  and  complemented  by  Sri  Lanka’s  Second  National 
Communication preparation process, and will complement ongoing government 
efforts to develop a separate national adaptation policy framework. The TA will 
assist  relevant  line  agencies  to  plan  and  develop  a  portfolio  of  priority  and 
practical projects focused on climate change adaptation. To do this, a review of 
the Government’s Green Lanka Programme, among other relevant government 
planning documents, will be undertaken—together with coordinated consultations 
with relevant government line agencies and departments spanning a variety of 
sectors (agriculture, fisheries, water, etc). Assistance through the TA will be 
provided  for  project  concepts  to  be  formulated,  specifically  targeting  climate 
change adaptation interventions. Finally, an investment plan for accessing grant 
financing  based  on  the  adaptation  strategy  will  be  developed  in  close 
coordination with the MOFP.

4   
(ii)  Partners Forum. The TA will also build on ADB’s experience elsewhere in the 
Asia  Pacific,  which  has  demonstrated  the  benefit  of  developing  member 
countries  developing  a  coordinated  strategic  program  for  climate  change 
adaptation  that  identifies  areas  where  international  financing  can  best  be 
provided, and will aim to present such strategy to external partners at a Partners 
Forum to negotiate financing options. The TA is intended to build on lessons 
learned from the convening of a Partners Forum to support national efforts aimed 
at tapping various funding sources that are being created for climate change 
adaptation globally, and channel these for the benefit of Sri Lanka’s Strategic 
Program for Climate Change Adaptation and medium-term investment plan. The 
MOFP will play a significant role in this effort, especially in the development of 
the medium-term investment plan and tapping into concessional funding sources. 
The TA will strengthen the MOFP so that it will be in a better position to work with 
MENR to prepare and tap into funding sources. The TA will assist the MOFP in 
undertaking this role in line with obligations under the Bali Action Plan formulated 
by member countries of the UNFCCC at the 13th Conference of the Parties, and 
the outcomes of the first Finance Ministers Meeting on Climate Change where it 
was agreed that ministers of finance would take a more active role in integrating 
climate change issues into development planning.  
(iii)   Public information and awareness. An education, information, and awareness 
strategy will be developed and implemented to increase understanding of climate 
change  adaptation  risks  and  adaptation  responses  at  national,  local,  and 
community levels; and promote support for public spending for climate change 
adaptation.  
(iv)  Strengthening institutional framework. Sri Lanka’s technical capacity must be 
strengthened  to  handle  the  new  challenges  of  increasingly  destabilized 
environments  and  environment-dependent  economic  and  social  activities. 
Capacity at the national-level Climate Change Secretariat within MENR will be 
strengthened for integrating and coordinating central and district government 
institutions in climate change risk management processes. Simultaneously, the 
TA will support the strengthening of capacity among district and central level 
environmental  staff  through  climate  change  vulnerability  assessments, 
vulnerability mapping, and adaptation planning. The Project will be undertaken 
through a participatory process involving central government, provincial councils, 
and affected communities—resulting in hands-on training in climate change risk 
management processes. The TA will also assist MENR in preparing government 
responses  in  international  and  regional  climate  change  meetings  where  its 
strategic approach to climate change adaptation may be showcased.    
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
10.  The total cost of the TA (see Appendix 2) is estimated at $875,000 equivalent, $700,000 
of which will be financed on a grant basis by the Climate Change Fund.  The Government, 
through MENR, will finance the remaining $175,000 equivalent through provision of office space, 
transport, counterpart staff, data and analysis, and other administrative costs.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
11.  MENR, through its Climate Change Secretariat, will be the Executing Agency for the TA. 
It will appoint a technical director and/or national coordinator at a senior level. MENR will also

5
 
form a project preparatory working group including (i) specialists in agriculture, fisheries, forestry, 
coast conservation, and other relevant representative agencies nominated by the departments 
concerned; and (ii) an interdepartmental TA steering committee, chaired by the secretary of 
MENR,  including  representatives  from  the  Department  of  External  Resources,  MOFP,  the 
National Planning Department, and a group of renowned sector specialists to implement and 
guide the TA activities.  
 
12.  The TA will be implemented in three phases over 9 months from 2009 to 2010, with 
phases I and II to be completed over the first 6 months. Phases I and II will develop the strategic 
adaptation framework, adaptation strategy, and implementation and investment plan; and will 
complete  the  draft  final  report  and  final  report,  including  study  reports,  environmental 
assessment reports, social impact assessment reports, and communications report. Over the 
subsequent 3 months (phase III), the TA will provide support for pilot demonstration, additional 
training,  and  information  dissemination  related  activities.  All  equipment  for  the  TA  will  be 
processed according to ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time).  
 
13.  A team of international consultants will be engaged for 17 person-months and a team of 
national consultants for 28 person-months to help implement the TA. The consultants will be 
selected and engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, 
as amended from time to time). The TA will require international expertise in the following areas: 
team leader/strategic planning expert (8 person-months), environment specialist (4 person-
months), social and community development (mobilization) specialist (2 person months), and 
communications and education specialist (3 person-months). National consultants will include a  
deputy team leader (8 person-months), environment specialist (6 person-months), institutional 
and  community  development  specialist  (6  person-months),  and  communications/media 
specialist (6 person-months). Since the terms of reference of the consultants require highly 
specialized skills and production of independent studies and reports (sometimes in selected 
geographical regions of the island), all the relevant experts will not be available in house in a 
single firm, which reduces the flexibility in selecting the best team. Moreover, firms’ margins 
would significantly increase the costs of hiring consultants who could be recruited individually. 
Given ADB’s relatively recent entry into the climate change arena in Sri Lanka, it is anticipated 
that this TA will require more specialized management by the relevant ADB project officer which 
will lead to a more enhanced quality output. Therefore, individual consultants will be engaged 
for cost-effective and efficient implementation of the TA within the available budget. Outline 
terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
14.  The TA progress will be measured, as stipulated in the design and monitoring framework 
(Appendix 1). The TA outputs will be disseminated in national and regional workshops, and as 
part of local level capacity building training workshops.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Sri Lanka for Strengthening Capacity for Climate Change Adaptation, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be implemented in three phases over 9 months from 
2009 to 2010, with phases I and II to be completed over the first 6 months. Phases I and II will 
develop  the  strategic  adaptation  framework,  adaptation  strategy,  and  implementation  and 
investment plan; and will complete the draft final report and final report, including study reports, 
environmental assessment reports, social impact assessment reports, and communications reports. 
Over the subsequent 3 months (phase III), the TA will provide support for pilot demonstration, 
additional training, and information dissemination related activities. The terms of reference of the 
consultants are detailed below. 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
2.  Strategic Planning Expert/Team Leader (8 person-months). The consultant will lead in 
formulating and developing the overall project by coordinating the inputs of government agencies 
and the TA team, and delivering quality TA outputs on time. The consultant should have the ability 
to (i) a robust strategic framework for climate change, (ii) design and manage an effective and 
participatory process to develop the change or adaptation strategy, (iii) liaise effectively with a 
range  of  development  partners  and  agencies,  (iv)  develop  and  manage  a  public  awareness 
campaign, (v) oversee training activities, (vi) facilitate workshops and consultative processes with 
all kinds of stakeholders, (vii) understand and devise some of the financing implications of a 
climate change adaptation strategy, and (viii) manage the overall project team. The scope of work 
will include but not be limited to these tasks: 
 
(i)  Prepare a detailed TA implementation and work plan to ensure timely TA outputs. 
(ii)  Organize briefings, baseline socioeconomic surveys, and stakeholder workshops; 
and help set up a mechanism for regular consultations, including the project steering 
committee. 
(iii)  Synthesize lessons learned from similar projects and summarize best practices for 
similar interventions. 
(iv)  Assess the institutional capacity of various agencies for undertaking climate change 
adaptation assessments, and make recommendations for sustainability. 
(v)  Establish  linkages  between  the  Climate  Change  Secretariat  in  the  Ministry  of 
Environment and Natural Resources (MENR) and other relevant line agencies on 
climate  change  adaptation  activities  and  their  overall  impact  on  mainstreaming 
climate  change  adaptation  across  relevant  sectors.  Based  on  this  assessment, 
provide  specific  recommendations  for  more  efficient,  streamlined,  and  effective 
sectoral coordination. 
(vi)  With  the  assistance  of  the  international  environment  specialist,  review  existing 
environment  and  development  plans,  regulations,  and  policies;  and  undertake 
preparation of a cohesive climate change adaptation and development strategy. 
(vii)  Based on the surveys, consultations, and assessment—and with the assistance of 
the  international  environment  specialist—prepare  a  cohesive  climate  change 
adaptation  strategy  for  the  Government  that  takes  into  account  other  relevant 
strategies and plans. 
(viii)  With the assistance of the international environment specialist, review the technical 
robustness of the climate change adaptation proposals from relevant line ministries, 
and provide recommendations for further development and finalization for funding. 
(ix)  In consultation with the TA team, identify ways to address (a) MENR and specifically 
the Climate Change Secretariat’s institutional capacity to implement and sustain

project  activities,  and  (b)  required  capacity  building  and  training  programs  for 
climate change adaptation activities. 
(x)  Coordinate to ensure timely preparation of social and environmental assessments, 
and frameworks. 
(xi)  In consultation with other TA team and key stakeholders, formulate the overall 
climate  change  adaptation  strategy,  implementation  plan,  and  accompanying 
investment plan—including implementation arrangements and estimated costs. 
(xii)  Prepare timely project reports, including the inception, midterm, and draft and final 
reports for the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Government. 
(xiii)  In close coordination with the TA consultants and the Executing Agency, convene a 
Partners Forum. 
(xiv)  Assume overall responsibility for preparing all TA outputs and reports for submission 
to ADB and the Executing Agency. 
(xv)  Based  on  overall  findings,  prepare  a  Regional  Best  Practice  note  relating  to 
Sri Lanka’s experiences in climate change adaptation. 
 
3.  Environment Specialist (4 person-months). The expert will be responsible for guiding all 
tasks undertaken by the national environmental specialist, following relevant ADB guidelines. The 
consultant  will  undertake  tasks  according  to  ADB’s  Environment  Policy  (2002)  and  the 
environmental laws and regulations of the Government and will do the following:  
 
(i)  Analyze the role of public sector investments in the agriculture; fisheries; health; and 
water sector, and other relevant line agencies; and identify priority climate change 
adaptation projects for possible financing. 
(ii)  In consultation with the national experts, review the Government’s climate change 
adaptation policy framework, and incorporate specific measures for climate change 
proofing and risk resilience in the design. 
(iii)  Assist the team leader in guiding preparation of the climate change adaptation 
strategy. 
(iv)  Assist the team leader to develop practical procedures and approaches for baseline 
surveys, and impact monitoring of subsequent projects. 
(v)  In consultation with the team leader, prepare tentative project costs for the identified 
portfolio of climate change adaptation projects for funding. 
(vi)  Assist the team leader in finalizing the relevant TA reports. 
(vii)  Define  arrangements  and  programs  for  project  management  and  institutional 
strengthening for the specific environmental issues, particularly those relating to 
district level  environmental  training  in  conducting  vulnerability  assessments  and 
mapping.  
 
4.   Social and Community Development Specialist (2 person-months). The consultant will 
do the following:  
 
(i)  Guide all the tasks undertaken by the institutional and community development 
specialist.  
(ii)  Identify the beneficiaries, communities, and stakeholders expected to be affected by 
the TA. 
(iii)  Review,  assess,  and  prepare  the  social  impacts  of  the  TA  interventions  in 
accordance with ADB guidelines. 
(iv)  Prepare  socioeconomic  and  poverty  profiles  for  stakeholder  consultations  by 
collecting information through statistical records, field surveys, and key informant 
interviews.

12           Appendix 3 
 
(v)  Perform a facilitating role to the strategy development process by collating and 
matching knowledge and adaptation strategies. This will be the initial step, which is 
an extension of the stakeholder mapping exercise that has already been conducted. 
Identify in greater scope what adaptation strategies are taking place on the ground, 
and as far as possible factors that drive these adaptation strategies. 
(vi)  Based on an assessment of the local knowledge base, match these with what 
experts see as priority coping measures and or elements and with what service 
providers and or partners are carrying out in line with adaptation criteria. This will 
require liaising with a range of stakeholders to work toward creating synergies 
between international, national, and local level knowledge; and the actions already 
taking place to identify what works best in Sri Lanka. 
(vii)  Develop  a  set  of  principles  that  will  straddle  the  international  and  national 
knowledge base, and enable the development of a policy orientation specific to 
Sri Lanka.  The  information  gathering  and  matching  process  should  lead  to  the 
identification of knowledge groups and gaps, identification of priority areas based on 
the strategic principles; key adaptation processes that can have multiplier effects 
and  partnerships and services that are needed to strengthen adaptation strategies. 
(viii)  Ensure that the climate change adaptation strategy developed is geared to one that 
is focused on increasing information; capacities; and the identification of adaptation 
strategies and partnerships that are needed for multiplier effects. Simultaneously 
identify targets, indicators, and action plans through consultation with the various 
stakeholders to direct future implementation. 
(ix)  Assess  the  different  coping  and  adaptation  strategies  of  people  when  project 
strategies and activities will require them to change specific behavior and attitude 
toward managing and utilizing the environment and natural resources.    
(x)  Recommend measures to enhance benefits and minimize adverse impacts on all 
stakeholders. 
(xi)  Provide adequate coverage for investigations and consultations with stakeholders, 
in relation to potential impacts and/or possible enhancement of project benefits.  
(xii)  Provide recommendations for continuing the consultation process with stakeholders 
during project implementation and beyond. 
 
5.  Communications and Education Specialist (3 person-months). The consultant will be 
responsible  for  developing  an  education,  information,  and  awareness  strategy  to  increase 
understanding of climate change adaptation risks and appropriate adaptation responses at the 
national, local, and community levels. He/she will assist in the development of training programs 
that seek to strengthen staff capacity at the national, provincial, and district level to conduct climate 
change vulnerability assessments, vulnerability mapping, and adaptation planning. The scope of 
work will include but will not be limited to these tasks: 
 
(i)  Using a participatory process, design a hands-on training program in climate change 
risk management processes.  
(ii)  Assume overall responsibility for the development of production, distribution, and 
broadcast of short video and radio feature items on various impacts of climate 
change adaptation responses to specific target audiences. 
(iii)  Design and conduct climate change adaptation workshops to familiarize participants 
with various aspects of climate change adaptation and mitigation efforts, including 
energy  efficiency,  sustainable  transportation,  renewable  energy,  and  climate 
proofing—including ADB programs supporting these efforts.

Appendix 3  13 
B.  National Consultants 
 
6.   Climate Change Specialist/Deputy Team Leader (8 person-months). The consultant will 
assist the team leader in coordinating activities related to the project preparatory working group, 
steering committee and conducting TA workshops. The consultant will do the following:  
 
(i)  Assist the team leader to review and assess the institutional capacity of various 
agencies  for  undertaking  climate  change  adaptation  assessments,  and  make 
recommendations for sustainability. 
(ii)  Conduct  supplementary  studies,  in  close  coordination  with  the  relevant  line 
agencies,  to  update  and  improve  the  adaptation  portfolio  of  projects  for  the 
development of a suitable financing strategy. 
(iii)  Assist the team leader in preparing relevant sections of required reports. 
(iv)  Assist in the coordination and logistical arrangements required for convening the 
Partners Forum workshop, including liaising with government counterparts.  
(v)  Assist the team leader and deputy team leader in preparing various progress reports.  
  
7.  Environment Specialist (6 person-months). The consultant will do the following:  
 
(i)  Document  and  record  the  role  of  public  sector  investments  in  the  agriculture; 
fisheries; health; water sector; and other relevant line agencies; and identify priority 
climate change adaptation projects for possible financing. 
(ii)  Provide inputs in consultation with the national experts to the Government’s climate 
change adaptation policy framework, and incorporate specific measures for climate 
change proofing and incorporation of risk resilience in the design. 
(iii)  Assist the international environment specialist in the identification of sector-specific 
priorities for incorporation in the development of the climate change adaptation 
strategy. 
(iv)  Assist  the  international  environment  specialist  and  the  team  leader  to  develop 
practical procedures and approaches for baseline surveys, and impact monitoring of 
subsequent projects selected for development of the investment strategy. 
(v)  In consultation with the team leader, prepare tentative project costs for the identified 
portfolio of climate change adaptation projects for funding. 
(vi)  Assist the environment specialist in finalizing the relevant TA reports. 
(vii)  Undertake a review of related environmental programs for project management and 
institutional strengthening, which could be remodeled to incorporate climate change 
proofing measures and training needs for local and or district environmental officers.  
(viii)  Assist the team leader and deputy team leader in preparing various progress reports.   
 
8.   Institutional and Community Development Specialist (6 person-months). The specialist 
should have relevant qualifications in social sector surveys and extensive work experience in 
conducting stakeholder consultations and participatory processes for engagement. The consultant 
will do the following:  
 
(i)  Assist the team leader and deputy team leader in the necessary inputs relating to 
various progress and other reports.  
(ii)  Assess the existing regulatory framework in terms of responsiveness to the aims of 
the TA. 
(iii)  Provide technical support to the Executing Agency in developing reports, review 
procedures, public consultations, and disclosures.

14           Appendix 3 
 
(iv)  Provide adequate coverage for investigations and consultations with stakeholders, 
in relation to potential impacts and/or possible enhancement of project benefits. 
(v)  Provide recommendations for continuing the consultation process with stakeholders 
during project implementation and beyond. 
 
9.   Communications and/or Media Specialist (6 person-months). The specialist should have 
relevant qualifications in communications and media studies development. Specific tasks include 
the following: 
 
(i)  Assist in the design, development, and production of media products and materials 
to communicate sustainable development. 
(ii)  Assist in the development of a  climate change adaptation communications strategy. 
(iii)  Assist in the public communication and dissemination of climate change science, 
technology, and environment using print, radio, and web media. 
(iv)  Assist  in  the  planning,  facilitating,  and  synthesizing  of  public  consultations  on 
climate change adaptation strategies. 
(v)  Assist the team leader and deputy team leader in preparing various progress reports.
